image.altText: A split image of a smiling young woman with brown hair, a young man wearing sunnies and cap, and young blond woman hugging a dog

items.synopsis: NSW Premier Chris Minns announces that a support fund will be co-managed by the state government and Rotary Australia, providing relief to survivors, victims and their immediate families.

title.children: NSW Premier gives update on wedding bus crash tragedy after donating $100k

image.altText: donald trump walks up plane stairs

items.synopsis: The former US president makes a statement in New Jersey after entering a not guilty plea to federal charges relating to his handling of classified national security records.

title.children: Donald Trump pleads not guilty to federal charges, as Republican rivals slam FBI, Justice Department

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The crowd chanted "USA" as Trump took to the microphone. He says today we witnessed an evil abuse of power ahead of a presidential election, and blamed Biden for election interference. His claims are not substantiated. "They will fail and we will win bigger and better than before," Trump says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The former president is speaking at Bedminster Golf Club

children.content: The crowd chanted "USA" as Trump took to the microphone.
He says today we witnessed an evil abuse of power ahead of a presidential election, and blamed Biden for election interference.
His claims are not substantiated.
Trump walking onto the stage, half an hour after his speech was due to begin.
(Reuters)
"They will fail and we will win bigger and better than before," Trump says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Supporters and journalists are awaiting Trump's arrival at Bedminster Golf Club, where he is expected to make a statement. He flew out of Miami a couple of hours ago now.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump is about to give a speech in New Jersey

children.content: Supporters and journalists are awaiting Trump's arrival at Bedminster Golf Club, where he is expected to make a statement.
He flew out of Miami a couple of hours ago now.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here he is boarding his personal plane at Miami International Airport. I mentioned earlier that he's expected to make a statement from New Jersey on the court proceedings in about 90 minutes.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump has left Miami and is heading back to New Jersey

children.content: Here he is boarding his personal plane at Miami International Airport.

props.alt: Donald Trump boards his personal plane.

children.content: (AP: Alex Brandon)
I mentioned earlier that he's expected to make a statement from New Jersey on the court proceedings in about 90 minutes.

props.alt: Donald Trump's personal plane seen leaving the tarmac.

children.content: (AP: Alex Brandon)

image.altText: Mikayla looks seriously into the camera, wearing glasses.

items.synopsis: As the cost of living soars, students are choosing to go without things like mental health care to get by, as a Canberra food pantry reports a 70 per cent increase in demand in 12 months.

title.children: Mikayla gave up therapy to make ends meet, and she's not the only young person making tough choices

image.altText: Donald Trump speaks to supporters at Versailles restaurant. There are two women standing on either side of him.

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump faces criminal charges for the second time in as many months. Here's how his day in court unfolded.

title.children: Trump's day in court featured a not guilty plea, a warning from the judge and a round of 'happy birthday' from supporters

image.altText: a young brunette woman smiling into the camera

items.synopsis: JM Lane had been living in Canada since early January and was on a road trip in British Columbia before she was due to start a finance job.

title.children: Canadian police find Brisbane woman's body while searching remote hiking trail

image.altText: A middle aged woman looks at documents  at her kitchen table

items.synopsis: Elisabetta Di Nardo has been battling with ANZ for almost two years for lending her money she says was based on inaccurate information provided without her knowledge.

title.children: Elisabetta says ANZ failed to verify her home loan application, now she's taking legal action

image.altText: An unidentifiable man in suit in a high rise office, photographed from behind.

items.synopsis: While a 5.75 per cent increase in award wages attracts widespread criticism, a new report reveals the nation's big business leaders are receiving an average 15 per cent base pay rise.

title.children: How much does your big boss get paid? These figures might give you a fair idea

image.altText: Vladimir Putin points his right ring finger upwards as he sits at a table near a mic.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin spends more than two hours giving some of his most detailed remarks about Russia's invasion of Ukraine in months, as the first independent confirmation of the results of Kyiv's counteroffensive come through from the frontlines.

image.altText: A smiling, young woman with long dark hair.

items.synopsis: Simone Strobel's naked body was found in Lismore in 2005. Last year Tobias Moran was charged over her death, but today prosecutors have withdrawn their case.

title.children: Charges dropped against man accused of cold case murder of German backpacker Simone Strobel

image.altText: Jennie and Ray give smile deeply at each other in an open-top car. They are in wedding dress and suit.

items.synopsis: A scrap of clothing found by a member of the public is believed to have prompted police to re-examine a mine shaft where the body of an amateur prospector — whose wife remains missing — was found eight years ago.

title.children: Scrap of clothing in mine shaft prompts fresh search eight years after body found

image.altText: A photo of a middle aged woman with blond hair and glasses in a white corridor

image.altText: A hand drops a brown glass bottle into a machine, with a screen next to it

image.altText: An illustration of two spiked lizards on rocks, one lizard has its mouth open with a visible navy blue tongue sticking out.

items.synopsis: Its official name is Tiliqua frangens, but its bulky bod and serious spiky armour mean it already has a range of colourful nicknames including "Mega Chonk" and "Chonkasaurus".

title.children: Giant prehistoric skink dubbed 'Mega Chonk' discovered in Dubbo region

image.altText: Sunlight enters Tam Pa Ling cave's steep entrance

items.synopsis: Bone fragments found in a mountain cave in northern Laos are the oldest evidence of modern humans in South-East Asia, suggesting our species was in the region much earlier than previously thought, say scientists.

title.children: Fossil discovery suggests humans lived in mainland South-East Asia 86,000 years ago. But what became of them is a mystery

image.altText: A woman works at a desk with three screens.

items.synopsis: Of all the things Australians can do to boost productivity, working harder is one of the least likely to make a difference, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Don't blame workers for falling productivity – we're not the ones holding it back

image.altText: A smiling man in a navy suit holds the state budget papers. Behind him outside the window is Adelaide Oval

items.synopsis: The South Australian government will report a quarter-of-a-billion-dollar deficit in Thursday's state budget — a major reversal on the surplus that was forecast six months ago.

title.children: SA plunges into the red, as treasurer blames increased spending in key policy areas

image.altText: dark-haired woman sits on some steps, cuddling her young, fair-haired daughter.

items.synopsis: When electrician Erin Bohanna moved to Gladstone with her family she already had work lined up. But after trying to secure daycare for her daughter, she realised she would not be able to take the position.

title.children: Tradie mum turns down dream job after being placed 110th on childcare waitlist

image.altText: The external prison with construction work underway

items.synopsis: The NSW Public Service Association wants the NSW Minister for Corrections to lower entry requirements and offer more incentives to attract new people into the profession.

title.children: Prison staff punched, bitten, spat on due to chronic shortages, union says

image.altText: An elderly man uses a paintbrush

items.synopsis: Aged care work is still stigmatised by other health professionals as dirty, difficult and low-status — more than most other jobs.

title.children: Is a 15 per cent pay rise enough to make you take this job?

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus smiles on the lane rope

items.synopsis: Ariarne Titmus will head for the world championships as underdog, but wonders how new record-holder Summer McIntosh will handle the pressure in their showdown.

title.children: Ariarne Titmus ready to 'pounce' on world record holder Summer McIntosh

image.altText: An AFL player eyes the football he holds in one hand as he prepares to kick.

items.synopsis: James Sicily is suspended for three weeks for a tackle on Hugh McCluggage, as Hawthorn attempted to use a doctor to explain another Hawk was to blame for the incident.

title.children: Hawks captain banned over tackle despite club's attempts to place blame on another player

image.altText: A generic image of the Wallabies jersey as worn by a player during a 2022 Test match.

items.synopsis: With the competition for sporting talent in Australia the fiercest it has ever been, rugby union needs to look beyond its traditional grassroots base in private schools if it wants to stay relevant, writes Luke Pentony.

title.children: If Australian rugby wants to thrive in the 'golden decade', it needs to ditch the private schoolboy image

image.altText: Badiucao in front of artwork, which depicts Chinese official and smaller art work pieces on the floor, wearing masks.

items.synopsis: The Chinese government is attempting to shut down an exhibition in Poland showing works by Chinese-Australian artist Badiucao, which an official says "hurt Chinese people's feelings".

title.children: Artist calls on Australia for help in 'very absurd' attempt from Chinese government to stop his exhibition

image.altText: A woman of Asian heritage holding a microphone and speaking on stage.

items.synopsis: Jocelyn Chia, a New York-based comedian, stirred controversy in Malaysia and Singapore after she posted on social media a clip of her live comedy set in which she joked about the plane that went missing nine years ago with 239 people onboard.

title.children: Malaysia to investigate comedian over joke about missing flight MH370

image.altText: A pile of US bank notes

items.synopsis: Investor optimism that the US Federal Reserve will keep rates on hold this week drives stocks higher. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US interest rate pause expected as inflation slows, ASX gains

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just minutes into the session, but it's been a modestly positive start for the local share market. The All Ordinaries index is around 0.4 per cent higher. Major miners are doing the heavy lifting, with BHP (+2.5%) and Fortescue (+2.9%) rising substantially. On the flipside, CSL shares have dropped sharply — down 7.9 per cent, dragging the health care sector with them. The biotech firm earlier flagged a bigger profit hit from foreign currency exchange rates than previously forecast. RBC Capital Markets analyst Craig Wong-Pan said CSL's update was disappointing in terms of its guidance for the next financial year. In the retail sector, Myer shares are down by 4 per cent, which may have something to do with a drop in sales at rival David Jones, as reported by The Australian. Elsewhere in the sector, retailers are mostly higher including Harvey Norman (+0.5%), Premier Investments (+0.9%) and JB Hi-Fi (+1%).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX on the up in early trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With not long to go until the local share market opens, retail stocks will be ones to watch, after a report in The Australian newspaper revealed leaked documents from David Jones. The department store has reportedly seen a double-digit drop in sales across city, suburban and regional stores. A David Jones spokesperson told The Australian that June was traditionally a quieter month for retail but the Reserve Bank's 12 interest rate rises were weighing on shoppers. While David Jones isn't listed on the stock exchange, rival retailers, such as fellow department store player Myer, are — so it will be interesting to see if they see any drop in share price at the open. Last week's interest rate hike and slowing economic growth highlighted the challenges facing the retail sector, amid further signs households are cutting back their discretionary spending.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Retail stocks ones to watch this session

children.content: With not long to go until the local share market opens, retail stocks will be ones to watch, after
a report in The Australian newspaper
revealed leaked documents from David Jones.
The department store has reportedly seen a double-digit drop in sales across city, suburban and regional stores.
A David Jones spokesperson told The Australian that June was traditionally a quieter month for retail but the Reserve Bank's 12 interest rate rises were weighing on shoppers.

While David Jones isn't listed on the stock exchange, rival retailers, such as fellow department store player Myer, are — so it will be interesting to see if they see any drop in share price at the open.
Last week's interest rate hike and slowing economic growth highlighted the challenges facing the retail sector, amid further signs households are cutting back their discretionary spending.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The banking and financial services regulator APRA is fining OnePath Custodians almost $1.5 million dollars. The regulator says OnePath failed to direct member funds to low cost MySuper products, which are supposed to be the default option when someone doesn't advise where they would like their money invested. OnePath is a superannuation trustee owned by Insignia Financial, previously known as IOOF, and has approximately 700,000 members and $35 billion in funds under management. It has been hit with infringement notices totalling $1.46 million for failing to direct 125 member contributions to a MySuper product from mid-last year onwards. "In addition to today's enforcement action, APRA is closely monitoring OPC to ensure any members who suffered financial losses as a result of these breaches are fully compensated as soon as possible," APRA Deputy Chair Margaret Cole said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Super fund fined for not putting member funds in no-frills accounts

children.content: The banking and financial services regulator APRA is fining OnePath Custodians almost $1.5 million dollars.

The regulator says OnePath failed to direct member funds to low cost MySuper products, which are supposed to be the default option when someone doesn't advise where they would like their money invested.
OnePath is a superannuation trustee owned by Insignia Financial, previously known as IOOF, and has approximately 700,000 members and $35
billion in funds under management.
It has been hit with infringement notices totalling $1.46 million for failing to direct 125 member contributions to a MySuper product from mid-last year onwards.

"In addition to today's enforcement action, APRA is closely monitoring OPC to ensure any members who suffered financial losses as a result of these breaches are fully compensated as soon as possible," APRA Deputy Chair Margaret Cole said.

image.altText: Brittany Higgins walking alongside another woman, with a man walking behind her.

title.children: Cormac McCarthy, celebrated author of No Country for Old Men and The Road, dies at 89

image.altText: A man with a face white with sunscreen walks across a rocky plain toward the camera with a dune in the background.

items.synopsis: The challenge of sandy dunes and rocky plains lures more than 100 people into the desert to experience Australia's natural beauty, heat, and solitude.

title.children: Why are runners flocking to outback Queensland for a 100km desert race? In the words of one participant, 'why not?'
